column1: F.D.A. Clears Johnson & Johnson’s Shot, the Third Vaccine for U.S.
column2: The authorization of a third Covid-19 vaccine will bring millions more doses within days. But health officials worry that some people will see the vaccine as the inferior choice.
column3: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere

column1: New Findings on 2 Ways Children Become Seriously Ill From the Coronavirus
column2: A large study found that young people hospitalized with acute Covid-19 have symptoms and characteristics that differ from those with a Covid-linked inflammatory syndrome.

column1: A New Coronavirus Variant Is Spreading in New York, Researchers Report
column2: The variant contains a mutation thought to help the virus dodge the immune system, scientists said.

column1: On the Post-Pandemic Horizon, Could That Be … a Boom?
column2: Signs of economic life are picking up, and mounds of cash are waiting to be spent as the virus loosens its grip.

column1: 2.5 Million Women Left the Work Force During the Pandemic. Harris Sees a ‘National Emergency.’
column2: “In one year,” Vice President Kamala Harris said, “the pandemic has put decades of the progress we have collectively made for women workers at risk.”

column1: Covid Vaccines for Kids Are Coming, but Not for Many Months
column2: Pfizer and Moderna are testing their vaccines on children 12 and older and hope to have results by the summer.

column1: A W.H.O. Researcher on His Trip to China Seeking Origins of the Virus
column2: An interview with Peter Daszak, an animal disease specialist, just after his return from an investigative research mission to Wuhan, the site of the original Covid outbreak, and surrounding areas.

column1: Colleges Vowed a Safer Spring. Then Students, and Variants, Arrived.
column2: Many universities instituted new testing protocols, hoping to avoid the problems of the fall. But coronavirus variants and uncooperative students have already driven outbreaks.
column3: By Stephanie Saul and Shawn Hubler

column1: China Scores a Public Relations Win After W.H.O. Mission to Wuhan
column2: Experts with the global health agency endorsed critical parts of Beijing’s narrative, even some parts that independent scientists question.

column1: France’s Latest Covid Measure: Letting Workers Eat at Their Desks
column2: The coronavirus pandemic has already upended eating habits in a country where the table is a sacred space. Now it is taking its toll on a symbol of work-life balance.

column1: What Can Covid-19 Teach Us About the Mysteries of Smell?
column2: The virus’s strangest symptom has opened new doors to understanding our most neglected sense.

column1: People of Color Face the Most Pandemic Housing Insecurity
column2: Census Bureau data show how households have struggled to stay current on rent and mortgage payments during the pandemic.

column1: Weekly Health Quiz: Diet, Weight and Covid
column2: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

column1: Germans Clamor for Covid Vaccines, but Shun AstraZeneca’s Offering
column2: Hundreds of thousands of AstraZeneca doses are sitting unopened as many Germans reject the vaccine over fears it is “second-class” compared to the one developed by BioNTech and Pfizer.

column1: Has China Done Too Well Against Covid-19?
column2: The country doesn’t care enough about vaccination because of a false sense of security.

column1: Landlords Eager for Covid-Era Revamps Are Finding Hungry Investors
column2: The growing attraction of short-term real estate loans during the pandemic is making it easier to borrow to refurbish properties.

column1: When Covid Hit Nursing Homes, Part 2: ‘They’re Not Giving Us an Ending’
column2: In the final part of our exploration of what happened in New York’s nursing homes, we ask: How did the decisions made by Gov. Andrew Cuomo contribute to the crisis?

column1: Entering uncharted territory, the U.S. counts 500,000 Covid-related deaths.
column2: In a single year, Covid-19 became a leading cause of death in the United States, rivaling heart disease and cancer, and has driven life expectancy down sharply.
column3: By Lucy Tompkins, Mitch Smith, Julie Bosman and Bryan Pietsch

column1: At-Home Coronavirus Testing Is Here
column2: But does it work?

column1: Vulnerable Inmates Left in Prison as Covid Rages
column2: At a federal compound in Connecticut, inmates in precarious health “are like sitting ducks,” one lawyer said.

column1: On Taiwan’s New Passport, the Incredible Shrinking ‘Republic of China’
column2: Officials said the redesign was an attempt to disassociate Taiwanese citizens from those on the mainland, who faced travel restrictions amid the pandemic.

column1: Jobs Recovery Goes Into Reverse as Pandemic Takes a New Toll
column2: U.S. employment fell by 140,000 in December as virus cases surged. Leisure and hospitality businesses were hit hard, but some industries showed growth.

column1: New Data Triples Russia’s Covid-19 Death Toll
column2: The statistics agency said 230,000 more people died through November of this year than did in 2019, a hike attributable to the virus. Russia could jump to third among countries by number of Covid deaths.

column1: Early Vaccine Doubters Now Show a Willingness to Roll Up Their Sleeves
column2: Polls show that pervasive skepticism is melting, partly because of the high efficacy rates in trials and the images of real people getting the shot.

column1: Australia Begins Covid-19 Vaccination Campaign
column2: Australia began vaccinating its population against Covid-19 on Sunday. Jane Malysiak, 84, a resident of a nursing home in Sydney, and Prime Minister Scott Morrison were among the first to receive a vaccine.

column1: Johnson & Johnson Begins Covid-19 Vaccine Distribution
column2: Johnson & Johnson said it would start shipping millions of doses early this week after the Food and Drug Administration granted emergency use authorization for its vaccine on Saturday.

column1: White House Announces Increase in Covid-19 Vaccine Distribution
column2: On Tuesday, the White House press secretary Jen Psaki announced that federal vaccine distribution would increase. Ms. Psaki also said that President Biden would visit Texas to survey a vaccine site impacted by the recent winter storm.

column1: What to Know About California’s Covid-19 Relief
column2: Monday: Information about who’s eligible for state pandemic aid and how to get it. Also: The Golden Globes.
column3: By Priya Arora and Jill Cowan

column1: See How Covid-19 Has Tested the Limits of Hospitals and Staff
column2: Throughout the past year, the long stays and close monitoring required to care for Covid-19 patients have presented an uphill battle for medical workers.
column3: By John Keefe, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas and Sheri Fink

column1: Helping People Find Covid-19 Vaccines Is Aim of C.D.C.-Backed Site
column2: VaccineFinder.org is an ambitious but limited attempt to simplify Americans’ search for vaccines.
column3: By Rebecca Robbins and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

column1: Meet the key members of Biden’s Covid-19 response team.
column2: Read more about the plans by top officials to move toward something resembling normalcy.

column1: Watch Live: Biden Delivers Remarks on Lives Lost to Covid-19
column2: On Monday, President Biden honors the lives lost to Covid-19 as the United States nears 500,000 deaths, followed by a candle-lighting ceremony.

column1: New Covid-19 Infections Have Fallen to Half in Europe, W.H.O. Says
column2: Heightened restrictions on social interaction have caused the rates of Covid-19 cases to fall in Europe. But the World Health Organization cautioned that new cases were still 10 times as high as they were last May.

column1: Should I Get a Covid-19 Vaccine When Others Need It More?
column2: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what should determine eligibility for the Covid-19 vaccine and more.

column1: A Dismal Spring Awaits Unless We Slow the Spread of Covid-19
column2: How soon life returns to normal depends on what we do now.
column3: By Ezekiel J. Emanuel, Rick Bright and Céline Gounder

column1: Covid-19 Is ‘Probably Going to End My Career’
column2: Being a nurse was already hard. But in the pandemic, it’s become almost impossible.

column1: Ohio Finds 4,000 Unreported Covid-19 Deaths
column2: Ohio officials said on Thursday they discovered about 4,000 overlooked Covid-19 deaths that occurred over the past several months after the state’s Health Department said the deaths had not been properly merged between the internal death certificate database and the federal database.

column1: Trump Was Sicker Than Acknowledged With Covid-19
column2: When he was hospitalized with the coronavirus in October, his blood oxygen levels had plunged and officials feared he was on the verge of being placed on a ventilator.
column3: By Noah Weiland, Maggie Haberman, Mark Mazzetti and Annie Karni

column1: The Biden administration buys 100,000 doses of a combination antibody treatment for high-risk Covid-19 patients.
column2: The government will pay $210 million for the doses, which Eli Lilly will ship by the end of March.

column1: California has now lost more people to Covid-19 than any other state in the U.S.
column2: A bleak reminder that the recent progress the state has made against the pandemic may be fragile.

column1: Share Your Memories of Someone You Lost to Covid-19
column2: We want to hear from those who have lost a teacher, a brother, a bandmate or any of the other more than 430,000 Americans who have died in the pandemic.

column1: White House Covid-19 Team Warns of Virus Variants
column2: Members of President Biden’s coronavirus response team said they are increasing surveillance of potentially dangerous Covid-19 mutations.

column1: How Full Are Hospital I.C.U.s Near You?
column2: See how many Covid-19 patients are being treated, and how many I.C.U. beds remain available, at individual U.S. hospitals.
column3: By Matthew Conlen, John Keefe, Lauren Leatherby and Charlie Smart

column1: Answers to All Your Questions About Getting Vaccinated for Covid-19
column2: Times reporters answered questions from readers about getting the vaccine, what to expect and what happens next.

column1: Never mind the skeptics, officials say: Hank Aaron’s death had nothing to do with the Covid-19 vaccine.
column2: Anti-vaccine activists, including Robert F. Kennedy Jr., are seizing on the baseball legend’s death to suggest — without evidence — that there might be a link to his Covid vaccination.
column3: By Rick Rojas and Denise Grady

column1: Watch Live: Biden Delivers Remarks on the Fight Against Covid-19
column2: President Biden addresses the fight against the coronavirus pandemic from the White House.

column1: Is It OK to Enroll in a Covid-19 Vaccine Trial If I Might Drop Out?
column2: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the importance of control groups and elderly parents’ risky behavior.

column1: A Covid Vaccine Side Effect, Enlarged Lymph Nodes, Can Be Mistaken for Cancer
column2: The condition is becoming more common as immunization rates increase. Experts are suggesting ways to ease patients’ fears and avoid needless testing.

column1: ‘It’s Numbing’: Nine Retired Nuns in Michigan Die of Covid-19
column2: The deaths add to what is becoming a familiar trend in the spread of the virus as it devastates religious congregate communities by infecting retired, aging populations of nuns and sisters.
column3: By Christine Hauser and Concepción de León

column1: How the Search for Covid-19 Treatments Faltered While Vaccines Sped Ahead
column2: Vaccine development exceeded everyone’s expectations. But the next few months will still bring many sick people — and doctors have woefully few drugs with which to treat them.

column1: France’s Latest Covid Measure: Letting Workers Eat at Their Desks
column2: The coronavirus pandemic has already upended eating habits in a country where the table is a sacred space. Now it is taking its toll on a symbol of work-life balance.

column1: These New Yorkers Are Signing Up Their Neighbors for the Vaccine
column2: New Yorkers living in public housing have struggled to get vaccinated. We spent time with some of them as they volunteered with a program focusing on door-to-door outreach.

column1: Virus Variant First Found in Britain Now Spreading Rapidly in U.S.
column2: A new study bolsters the prediction by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that the so-called B.1.1.7 variant will dominate Covid-19 cases by March.

column1: See Covid-19 Exposure Risk in Your County and a Guide for Daily Life Near You
column2: See the risk of exposure to the disease in your county, and read our county-specific guidance for common activities to help you lower your risk and protect your community.
column3: By Eleanor Lutz, Aliza Aufrichtig, Charlie Smart, Albert Sun, Rich Harris and Gabriel Gianordoli

column1: China Wanted to Show Off Its Vaccines. It’s Backfiring.
column2: Delays, inconsistent data, spotty disclosures and the country’s attacks on Western rivals have marred its ambitious effort to portray itself as a leader in global health.

column1: Inside a Nursing Home as Vaccine Arrives: ‘I Hope Everybody Takes It’
column2: At a Staten Island facility that was hit hard by the coronavirus, residents and staff members lined up to get a dose of the Covid vaccine. Here’s how the day went.
column3: By Christopher Occhicone and David Gonzalez

column1: Frustrations Boil at Pace of Vaccinations at Long-Term Care Facilities
column2: The Trump administration raised hopes of a speedy process for nursing homes and assisted living facilities. Patience is wearing thin.

column1: Hopes for Tokyo’s Summer Olympics Darken
column2: Organizers postponed the Olympic Games for one year last March. Nearly a year later, prospects are getting bleaker.

column1: Two Members of W.H.O. Team on Trail of Virus Are Denied Entry to China
column2: Beijing has repeatedly impeded the global inquiry into the emergence of the coronavirus. Two scientists on the team remained in Singapore after testing positive for antibodies.

column1: Disappointing Chinese Vaccine Results Pose Setback for Developing World
column2: Brazil says CoronaVac has an efficacy rate just over 50 percent, much lower than previously announced. More than 380 million doses have already been ordered.
column3: By Sui-Lee Wee and Ernesto Londoño

column1: Technology Executive Apologizes After Dozens of Event Attendees Contract Covid-19
column2: Peter Diamandis thought extensive testing could help create an “immunity bubble” for a conference in Culver City, Calif. It didn’t work. “I hope others can learn from my mistakes,” he said.

column1: California has now lost more people to Covid-19 than any other state in the U.S.
column2: A bleak reminder that the recent progress the state has made against the pandemic may be fragile.

column1: As Brazil faces record Covid-19 deaths, a variant-fueled surge and lagging vaccinations, Bolsonaro disparages masks.
column2: The president says that the pandemic precaution can lead to headaches, difficulty concentrating and a “decreased perception of happiness.”

column1: One Pfizer dose offers robust protection for those who have had Covid-19, studies find.
column2: Two new pieces of research add strong evidence to the case for giving just a single dose of the Pfizer vaccine to people who have antibodies against the virus.

column1: The televangelist Frederick K.C. Price has died at 89 of complications from Covid-19.
column2: Frederick K.C. Price, who founded a megachurch and televangelism broadcast that made him a popular voice for Black Christians, died on Friday evening of complications from Covid-19, a spokeswoman for the family said. He was 89.

column1: Another antibody therapy is authorized for high-risk Covid-19 patients.
column2: Researchers hope Eli Lilly’s new combination therapy will be better able to fight virus variants than a similar treatment already in use.

column1: Opera Singers Help Covid-19 Patients Learn to Breathe Again
column2: A six-week program developed by the English National Opera and a London hospital offers customized vocal lessons to aid coronavirus recovery.

column1: ‘What’s the Point?’ Young People’s Despair Deepens as Covid-19 Crisis Drags On
column2: Experts paint a grim picture of the struggle with lockdown isolation — a “mental health pandemic” that should be treated as seriously as containing the coronavirus.
column3: By Isabella Kwai and Elian Peltier

column1: For This College Athlete, Covid-19 Was Just the Start of a Nightmare
column2: After learning she had myocarditis, an inflammation of the heart that has been linked to some Covid cases, Vanderbilt basketball player Demi Washington spent months hoping she could play again someday.

column1: N.Y. Restaurant Fires Waitress Who Wouldn’t Get Covid-19 Vaccine
column2: Bonnie Jacobson, 34, said she was not necessarily opposed to getting vaccinated, but wanted to study the potential effect on fertility first.

column1: The Newest Diplomatic Currency: Covid-19 Vaccines
column2: India, China, the U.A.E. and others dole out donations in countries where they seek sway. In some cases, they are sending doses despite pressing needs at home.
column3: By Mujib Mashal and Vivian Yee

column1: New York Sues Amazon, Saying It Inadequately Protected Workers From Covid-19
column2: The case focuses on two of the company’s facilities in New York.

column1: Amazon Sues New York Attorney General to Block Covid-19 Charges
column2: The company said the attorney general, Letitia James, had overstepped her authority in investigating workplace safety.

column1: What the World Can Learn About Covid-19 From the Seahawks and Browns
column2: The N.F.L. rolled out a grand experiment to play a not-at-all socially distanced sport in a pandemic. The Times went behind the scenes with the Seattle Seahawks and the Cleveland Browns to understand how the science and the upheaval played out.
column3: By Robin Stein, Danielle Miller and Ken Belson

column1: Mapping Los Angeles’s Unequal Covid-19 Surge
column2: Monday: A New York Times interactive map shows the uneven toll of the virus, neighborhood by neighborhood, on the nation’s most populous county.

column1: What to Know About Covid-19 and the Super Bowl
column2: Players from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Kansas City Chiefs are being tested for the coronavirus more often, and just 25,000 fans will attend the game.

column1: A French Nun Turns 117 After Knocking Down Covid-19
column2: Sister André was expected to celebrate her victory against the virus and her birthday on Thursday with a feast, and a glass of Champagne.

column1: Because of Covid-19, Even Getting to the Australian Open Is a Battle
column2: Players not only must be quarantined upon arrival, but then they are mostly confined to their rooms.

column1: See How the Vaccine Rollout Is Going in Your County and State
column2: See where doses have gone, and who is eligible for a shot in each state.

column1: Lawmaker Promoted Stem Cell Therapy for Covid-19 in Fraud Scheme, U.S. Says
column2: Tricia Derges, a Republican state representative in Missouri, falsely claimed to patients at her medical clinic that she was injecting them with stem cells, prosecutors said.

column1: Behind the Lines of Britain’s Covid War
column2: The government has laid out plans for gradual reopening. But in cramped intensive care wards, teeming with patients and doctors near despair, the battle is unrelenting.
column3: By Andrew Testa and Alan Cowell

column1: C.D.C. Traces Covid Outbreaks in Gyms, Urging Stricter Precautions
column2: Coronavirus cases at fitness centers in Chicago and Honolulu were linked to carelessness about masks and symptoms, federal health officials found.

column1: One Case, Total Lockdown: Australia’s Lessons for a Pandemic World
column2: The country’s short, sharp responses have repeatedly subdued the virus and allowed a return to near normalcy. Now its model is being applied to Perth, its fourth-largest city.

column1: The Covid Emergency Must End
column2: We might be able to achieve normalcy by summer. Our leaders should embrace the possibility.

column1: When Covid Hit Nursing Homes, Part 1: ‘My Mother Died Alone’
column2: In the first of two episodes on what went wrong in New York’s nursing homes, we look at the crisis through the eyes of a bereaved daughter.

column1: Nursing Homes, Once Hotspots, Far Outpace U.S. in Covid Declines
column2: New cases among residents of nursing homes have dropped more than 80 percent since vaccines became available, and deaths have decreased by more than 65 percent.
column3: By Matthew Conlen, Sarah Mervosh and Danielle Ivory

column1: Biden Marks Covid Milestone in Emotional White House Ceremony
column2: Speaking somberly and drawing on his own personal experience, President Biden sought not only to honor the dead, but also to comfort those who have lost loved ones.
column3: By David E. Sanger and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

column1: D.C.’s Mayor Mourned Covid’s Unequal Toll. Her Sister Is the Latest Victim.
column2: As the number of coronavirus deaths in the city reached 1,000 this week, three-fourths of the dead were Black.
column3: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Campbell Robertson

column1: This 105-Year-Old Beat Covid. She Credits Gin-Soaked Raisins.
column2: Lucia DeClerck, the oldest resident of her New Jersey nursing home, tested positive for the virus on her 105th birthday, one day after her second vaccine shot.

column1: Which Vaccine Should You Get?
column2: When there are multiple shots of varying effectiveness, take whatever is available to you first.

column1: Ghana Receives First Vaccine Shipment Through Covax
column2: Ghana on Wednesday became the first country to receive a shipment of coronavirus vaccines through the World Health Organization’s Covax distribution program.

column1: Biden Announces 50 Million Vaccinations Since Taking Office
column2: President Biden said on Thursday that 50 million coronavirus vaccines have been administered since Jan. 20, a halfway point toward his goal of administering 100 million in his first 100 days in office.

column1: F.D.A.’s expert panel voted in favor of the Johnson & Johnson shot.
column2: With this last hurdle cleared, formal authorization of the one-dose vaccine is expected on Saturday and distribution within days.
column3: By Carl Zimmer, Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere

column1: Johnson & Johnson’s Vaccine Works Well and May Curb Virus Spread
column2: F.D.A. studies show the shot strongly protects against severe illness and may reduce spread of the virus. But the drugmaker has fallen short of initial production goals.
column3: By Carl Zimmer, Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere

column1: Give Biden a Chance? On Covid Aid, Some Trump Voters Just Might
column2: Republican leaders in Washington firmly oppose the president’s stimulus plan, but a sizable number of Trump voters support it, interviews and polls show.

column1: Norman Landsberg, Jeweler With a Friendly Touch, Dies at 94
column2: He designed and sold jewelry for 72 years from a booth in the diamond district in Manhattan. He died of Covid-related pneumonia.

column1: Patrick Filien, Peripatetic Basketball Coach, Dies at 51
column2: After assistant coaching jobs around the country, he found his dream job as the head coach at a small college in Albany, N.Y. He died of Covid-19.

column1: White House Coronavirus Team Works to Improve Mask Equitability
column2: The White House coronavirus task force said on Wednesday that it wants to improve mask equitability by sending more than 25 million masks to vulnerable communities.

column1: Honoring One Life Among 500,000
column2: In North Philadelphia, a family gathered for a last day with “The Best Mom Ever.”
column3: By Rachel Wisniewski and Shelby Knowles

column1: Claudette White, Innovative Tribal Judge, Dies at 49
column2: An advocate for her people, the Quechan of Southern California, she had been calling out injustice since the third grade. She died of Covid-19.

column2: In a single year, Covid-19 became a leading cause of death in the United States, rivaling heart disease and cancer, and has driven life expectancy down sharply.
column3: By Lucy Tompkins, Mitch Smith, Julie Bosman and Bryan Pietsch

column1: At-Home Coronavirus Testing Is Here
column2: But does it work?

column1: Vulnerable Inmates Left in Prison as Covid Rages
column2: At a federal compound in Connecticut, inmates in precarious health “are like sitting ducks,” one lawyer said.

column1: Behind the Lines of Britain’s Covid War
column2: The government has laid out plans for gradual reopening. But in cramped intensive care wards, teeming with patients and doctors near despair, the battle is unrelenting.
column3: By Andrew Testa and Alan Cowell

column1: The Newest Diplomatic Currency: Covid-19 Vaccines
column2: India, China, the U.A.E. and others dole out donations in countries where they seek sway. In some cases, they are sending doses despite pressing needs at home.
column3: By Mujib Mashal and Vivian Yee

column1: New York Sues Amazon, Saying It Inadequately Protected Workers From Covid-19
column2: The case focuses on two of the company’s facilities in New York.

column1: Amazon Sues New York Attorney General to Block Covid-19 Charges
column2: The company said the attorney general, Letitia James, had overstepped her authority in investigating workplace safety.

column1: What to Know About Covid-19 and the Super Bowl
column2: Players from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Kansas City Chiefs are being tested for the coronavirus more often, and just 25,000 fans will attend the game.

column1: Mapping Los Angeles’s Unequal Covid-19 Surge
column2: Monday: A New York Times interactive map shows the uneven toll of the virus, neighborhood by neighborhood, on the nation’s most populous county.

column1: What the World Can Learn About Covid-19 From the Seahawks and Browns
column2: The N.F.L. rolled out a grand experiment to play a not-at-all socially distanced sport in a pandemic. The Times went behind the scenes with the Seattle Seahawks and the Cleveland Browns to understand how the science and the upheaval played out.
column3: By Robin Stein, Danielle Miller and Ken Belson

column1: A French Nun Turns 117 After Knocking Down Covid-19
column2: Sister André was expected to celebrate her victory against the virus and her birthday on Thursday with a feast, and a glass of Champagne.

column1: See How the Vaccine Rollout Is Going in Your County and State
column2: See where doses have gone, and who is eligible for a shot in each state.

column1: Because of Covid-19, Even Getting to the Australian Open Is a Battle
column2: Players not only must be quarantined upon arrival, but then they are mostly confined to their rooms.

column1: Lawmaker Promoted Stem Cell Therapy for Covid-19 in Fraud Scheme, U.S. Says
column2: Tricia Derges, a Republican state representative in Missouri, falsely claimed to patients at her medical clinic that she was injecting them with stem cells, prosecutors said.

column1: Technology Executive Apologizes After Dozens of Event Attendees Contract Covid-19
column2: Peter Diamandis thought extensive testing could help create an “immunity bubble” for a conference in Culver City, Calif. It didn’t work. “I hope others can learn from my mistakes,” he said.

column1: California has now lost more people to Covid-19 than any other state in the U.S.
column2: A bleak reminder that the recent progress the state has made against the pandemic may be fragile.

column1: As Brazil faces record Covid-19 deaths, a variant-fueled surge and lagging vaccinations, Bolsonaro disparages masks.
column2: The president says that the pandemic precaution can lead to headaches, difficulty concentrating and a “decreased perception of happiness.”

column1: One Pfizer dose offers robust protection for those who have had Covid-19, studies find.
column2: Two new pieces of research add strong evidence to the case for giving just a single dose of the Pfizer vaccine to people who have antibodies against the virus.

column1: The televangelist Frederick K.C. Price has died at 89 of complications from Covid-19.
column2: Frederick K.C. Price, who founded a megachurch and televangelism broadcast that made him a popular voice for Black Christians, died on Friday evening of complications from Covid-19, a spokeswoman for the family said. He was 89.

column1: Another antibody therapy is authorized for high-risk Covid-19 patients.
column2: Researchers hope Eli Lilly’s new combination therapy will be better able to fight virus variants than a similar treatment already in use.

column1: Opera Singers Help Covid-19 Patients Learn to Breathe Again
column2: A six-week program developed by the English National Opera and a London hospital offers customized vocal lessons to aid coronavirus recovery.

column1: ‘What’s the Point?’ Young People’s Despair Deepens as Covid-19 Crisis Drags On
column2: Experts paint a grim picture of the struggle with lockdown isolation — a “mental health pandemic” that should be treated as seriously as containing the coronavirus.
column3: By Isabella Kwai and Elian Peltier

column1: For This College Athlete, Covid-19 Was Just the Start of a Nightmare
column2: After learning she had myocarditis, an inflammation of the heart that has been linked to some Covid cases, Vanderbilt basketball player Demi Washington spent months hoping she could play again someday.

column1: N.Y. Restaurant Fires Waitress Who Wouldn’t Get Covid-19 Vaccine
column2: Bonnie Jacobson, 34, said she was not necessarily opposed to getting vaccinated, but wanted to study the potential effect on fertility first.

column1: Johnson & Johnson’s Vaccine Offers Strong Protection but Fuels Concern About Variants
column2: The vaccine’s efficacy rate dropped from 72 percent in the United States to just 57 percent in South Africa, where a highly contagious variant is driving most cases.
column3: By Carl Zimmer, Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere

column1: These New Yorkers Are Signing Up Their Neighbors for the Vaccine
column2: New Yorkers living in public housing have struggled to get vaccinated. We spent time with some of them as they volunteered with a program focusing on door-to-door outreach.

column1: Virus Variant First Found in Britain Now Spreading Rapidly in U.S.
column2: A new study bolsters the prediction by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that the so-called B.1.1.7 variant will dominate Covid-19 cases by March.

column1: See Covid-19 Exposure Risk in Your County and a Guide for Daily Life Near You
column2: See the risk of exposure to the disease in your county, and read our county-specific guidance for common activities to help you lower your risk and protect your community.
column3: By Eleanor Lutz, Aliza Aufrichtig, Charlie Smart, Albert Sun, Rich Harris and Gabriel Gianordoli

column1: China Wanted to Show Off Its Vaccines. It’s Backfiring.
column2: Delays, inconsistent data, spotty disclosures and the country’s attacks on Western rivals have marred its ambitious effort to portray itself as a leader in global health.

column1: Inside a Nursing Home as Vaccine Arrives: ‘I Hope Everybody Takes It’
column2: At a Staten Island facility that was hit hard by the coronavirus, residents and staff members lined up to get a dose of the Covid vaccine. Here’s how the day went.
column3: By Christopher Occhicone and David Gonzalez

column1: Frustrations Boil at Pace of Vaccinations at Long-Term Care Facilities
column2: The Trump administration raised hopes of a speedy process for nursing homes and assisted living facilities. Patience is wearing thin.

column1: Hopes for Tokyo’s Summer Olympics Darken
column2: Organizers postponed the Olympic Games for one year last March. Nearly a year later, prospects are getting bleaker.

column1: Two Members of W.H.O. Team on Trail of Virus Are Denied Entry to China
column2: Beijing has repeatedly impeded the global inquiry into the emergence of the coronavirus. Two scientists on the team remained in Singapore after testing positive for antibodies.

column1: Disappointing Chinese Vaccine Results Pose Setback for Developing World
column2: Brazil says CoronaVac has an efficacy rate just over 50 percent, much lower than previously announced. More than 380 million doses have already been ordered.
column3: By Sui-Lee Wee and Ernesto Londoño

column1: On Taiwan’s New Passport, the Incredible Shrinking ‘Republic of China’
column2: Officials said the redesign was an attempt to disassociate Taiwanese citizens from those on the mainland, who faced travel restrictions amid the pandemic.

column1: Jobs Recovery Goes Into Reverse as Pandemic Takes a New Toll
column2: U.S. employment fell by 140,000 in December as virus cases surged. Leisure and hospitality businesses were hit hard, but some industries showed growth.

column1: New Data Triples Russia’s Covid-19 Death Toll
column2: The statistics agency said 230,000 more people died through November of this year than did in 2019, a hike attributable to the virus. Russia could jump to third among countries by number of Covid deaths.

column1: Early Vaccine Doubters Now Show a Willingness to Roll Up Their Sleeves
column2: Polls show that pervasive skepticism is melting, partly because of the high efficacy rates in trials and the images of real people getting the shot.

column1: Australia Begins Covid-19 Vaccination Campaign
column2: Australia began vaccinating its population against Covid-19 on Sunday. Jane Malysiak, 84, a resident of a nursing home in Sydney, and Prime Minister Scott Morrison were among the first to receive a vaccine.

column1: White House Announces Increase in Covid-19 Vaccine Distribution
column2: On Tuesday, the White House press secretary Jen Psaki announced that federal vaccine distribution would increase. Ms. Psaki also said that President Biden would visit Texas to survey a vaccine site impacted by the recent winter storm.

column1: Johnson & Johnson Begins Covid-19 Vaccine Distribution
column2: Johnson & Johnson said it would start shipping millions of doses early this week after the Food and Drug Administration granted emergency use authorization for its vaccine on Saturday.

column1: What to Know About California’s Covid-19 Relief
column2: Monday: Information about who’s eligible for state pandemic aid and how to get it. Also: The Golden Globes.
column3: By Priya Arora and Jill Cowan

column1: Helping People Find Covid-19 Vaccines Is Aim of C.D.C.-Backed Site
column2: VaccineFinder.org is an ambitious but limited attempt to simplify Americans’ search for vaccines.
column3: By Rebecca Robbins and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

column1: See How Covid-19 Has Tested the Limits of Hospitals and Staff
column2: Throughout the past year, the long stays and close monitoring required to care for Covid-19 patients have presented an uphill battle for medical workers.

column1: Vulnerable Inmates Left in Prison as Covid Rages
column2: At a federal compound in Connecticut, inmates in precarious health “are like sitting ducks,” one lawyer said.

column2: The government has laid out plans for gradual reopening. But in cramped intensive care wards, teeming with patients and doctors near despair, the battle is unrelenting.
column3: By Andrew Testa and Alan Cowell

column1: One Case, Total Lockdown: Australia’s Lessons for a Pandemic World
column2: The country’s short, sharp responses have repeatedly subdued the virus and allowed a return to near normalcy. Now its model is being applied to Perth, its fourth-largest city.

column1: The Covid Emergency Must End
column2: We might be able to achieve normalcy by summer. Our leaders should embrace the possibility.

column1: When Covid Hit Nursing Homes, Part 1: ‘My Mother Died Alone’
column2: In the first of two episodes on what went wrong in New York’s nursing homes, we look at the crisis through the eyes of a bereaved daughter.

column1: Nursing Homes, Once Hotspots, Far Outpace U.S. in Covid Declines
column2: New cases among residents of nursing homes have dropped more than 80 percent since vaccines became available, and deaths have decreased by more than 65 percent.

column1: Tyler Perry Gets Covid-19 Vaccine on TV to Reassure Black Skeptics
column2: The Madea creator and studio head talks about the history of the medical and government establishment’s exploitation of Black people.

column1: Biden Marks Covid Milestone in Emotional White House Ceremony
column2: Speaking somberly and drawing on his own personal experience, President Biden sought not only to honor the dead, but also to comfort those who have lost loved ones.

column1: D.C.’s Mayor Mourned Covid’s Unequal Toll. Her Sister Is the Latest Victim.

column3: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Campbell Robertson

column1: This 105-Year-Old Beat Covid. She Credits Gin-Soaked Raisins.
column2: Lucia DeClerck, the oldest resident of her New Jersey nursing home, tested positive for the virus on her 105th birthday, one day after her second vaccine shot.

column1: Lessons From Los Angeles’s Deadly Winter
column2: Monday: A Times reporter who spent days inside Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital at the height of the surge discusses what we should learn.

column1: Biden administration officials tried to tamp down expectations for supplies of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine.
column2: The committee’s approval echoed the Food and Drug Administration’s decision on Saturday to authorize the vaccine for emergency use.

column2: A short film offering a firsthand perspective of the brutality of the pandemic inside a Covid-19 I.C.U.

column1: Russians Escape North Korea on a Hand-Pushed Railcar
column2: Russia said some of its diplomats and their family members, including children, had used creative means to leave North Korea, which closed its borders over a year ago because of the pandemic.
column3: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Mike Ives

column1: Can’t Get a Covid Vaccine? In This County, Everybody is Eligible
column2: The rural area outside Phoenix is one of the first places in the U.S. to open vaccinations up to the general public. This is what success looks like.

column1: State Lawmakers Defy Governors in a Covid-Era Battle for Power
column2: Legislators across the country, mostly Republicans, are moving to strip the powers of governors, many of them Democrats, who have taken on extraordinary authority to fight the pandemic.

column1: How the Pandemic Nearly Tore Israel Apart
column2: Lockdowns brought tensions between secular and ultra-Orthodox communities to the boiling point. The political consequences could be felt for years to come.

column1: Prime Minister Modi of India Is Vaccinated
column2: On Monday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India was vaccinated against the coronavirus. The country is beginning a large inoculation effort using the Oxford-AstraZeneca and the Covaxin vaccines.
